verses.text: After we had escaped, we found out that the island was called Malta.
verses.comment: Paul and his companions reach safety on Malta, fulfilling the earlier prediction of being cast on an island (Acts 27:26).

verses.text: The local people showed us unusual kindness, for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all, because it had begun to rain and was cold.
verses.comment: The 'unusual kindness' reflects themes of hospitality found throughout Scripture (Heb. 13:2). The local people’s actions are reminders of God using outsiders for His providence.

verses.text: When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and laid them on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat and fastened onto his hand.
verses.comment: Paul’s act shows his humility—he serves alongside the others. His encounter with the viper fulfills Jesus’ promise in Mark 16:18 about handling serpents without harm.

verses.text: When the local people saw the snake hanging from his hand, they said to one another, 'This man must be a murderer; even though he has escaped from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live.'
verses.comment: The Maltese interpret events through their pagan beliefs. This sets up a contrast that will highlight God’s sovereignty over fate.

verses.text: But he shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.
verses.comment: Paul’s preservation visibly demonstrates the authority and protection God gives to His apostles, indicating divine approval and setting an example of faith.

verses.text: They were expecting him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead; but after waiting a long time and seeing nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and began to say that he was a god.
verses.comment: A familiar pattern arises as the people swing from condemnation to idolizing Paul, as also happened in Lystra (Acts 14:11-12). This episode reveals the tendency of humans to misinterpret divine intervention.

verses.text: Now in the neighborhood of that place were lands belonging to the chief man of the island, named Publius, who received us and hosted us warmly for three days.
verses.comment: Publius’s hospitality demonstrates the openness of leaders to the gospel message and anticipates the Christian tradition of hospitality and care for travelers.

verses.text: It happened that the father of Publius lay sick in bed with fever and dysentery. Paul went in to see him, and after praying, he laid his hands on him and healed him.
verses.comment: Paul’s healing recalls apostolic miracles performed by Christ’s power (Matt. 10:8). The laying on of hands prefigures later sacramental practices for healing and ordination.

verses.text: When this had happened, the rest of the people on the island who had diseases came and were cured.
verses.comment: Paul’s ministry brings widespread healing, echoing Jesus’ ministry of bodily and spiritual healing, revealing the continuity of apostolic authority.

verses.text: They honored us in many ways; and when we were ready to set sail, they provided us with everything we needed.
verses.comment: God provides for His servants through human generosity, reflecting a pattern of providence seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: After three months, we set sail in a ship that had wintered in the island, a ship of Alexandria, with the figurehead of the Twin Gods.
verses.comment: The use of a ship with pagan symbols (the Twin Gods, Castor and Pollux) demonstrates God’s sovereignty over all things, whether sacred or secular.

verses.text: Putting in at Syracuse, we stayed there for three days.
verses.comment: Luke carefully records the journey, providing historical and geographical accuracy for the events.

verses.text: From there we set sail and arrived at Rhegium. After one day, a south wind came up, and on the second day we came to Puteoli.
verses.comment: The continued journey toward Rome marks the progression of the gospel to the heart of the empire.

verses.text: There we found brothers and were invited to stay with them for seven days. Then we came to Rome.
verses.comment: Paul finds an established Christian community in Italy, fulfilling the universal mission of the Church (Rom. 1:7). The seven-day stay hints at the sacred rhythms found in weekly worship.

verses.text: The brothers there, when they heard about us, came as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.
verses.comment: The mutual encouragement between Paul and the believers reflects the communion and unity of the Church (Rom. 1:12).

verses.text: When we entered Rome, Paul was allowed to live by himself, with a soldier who guarded him.
verses.comment: Paul’s relatively free conditions in Rome indicate a level of respect and recognition for his status, allowing his ministry to continue.

verses.text: After three days, he called together the leaders of the Jews. When they had assembled, he said to them, 'Men and brothers, although I had done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.'
verses.comment: Paul begins with respect for Jewish customs and affirms his own fidelity, pointing out the continuity between the old covenant and the new.

verses.text: When they had examined me, they wanted to release me, because there was no basis for a death sentence against me.
verses.comment: As before, Roman authorities find Paul innocent of charges deserving death, showing that Christianity was not in conflict with justice or the law.

verses.text: But when the Jews objected, I was forced to appeal to Caesar—not that I had any charge to bring against my own nation.
verses.comment: Paul’s appeal to Caesar advances the gospel to the center of world power. His loyalty to his nation is also evident.

verses.text: For this reason, I have asked to see you and speak with you, because it is for the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.
verses.comment: The 'hope of Israel' points to the resurrection and the coming Messiah, now fulfilled in Jesus (Acts 26:6-7). Paul’s imprisonment is for the sake of this promise.

verses.text: They said to him, 'We have received no letters from Judea concerning you, and none of the brothers who have come here have reported or spoken any evil about you.'
verses.comment: There are no official charges against Paul, opening the way for him to proclaim the gospel freely in Rome.

verses.text: 'But we desire to hear from you what your views are, for concerning this sect, we know that everywhere it is spoken against.'
verses.comment: Paul’s message is still viewed as controversial and frequently misunderstood, highlighting the challenge of the early Church’s mission.

verses.text: When they had appointed a day for him, they came in large numbers to his lodging. From morning till evening he explained and testified about the kingdom of God and tried to persuade them concerning Jesus, both from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets.
verses.comment: Paul’s method is to show continuity from Moses and the Prophets to Jesus, affirming the unity of God's revelation. This matches the apostolic tradition of interpreting Scripture through Christ.

verses.text: Some were convinced by what he said, but others did not believe.
verses.comment: As predicted, Christ is a sign that will be rejected by some and accepted by others, emphasizing the need for personal response to grace.

verses.text: Disagreeing among themselves, they began to leave after Paul had made one statement: 'The Holy Spirit was right in saying to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet,'
verses.comment: Paul appeals to the authority of the Holy Spirit speaking through Isaiah, modeling how the full Scriptures are preserved and interpreted by the early Church.

verses.text: 'Go to this people and say, "You will certainly hear but never understand; you will certainly see but never perceive."'
verses.comment: Quoting Isaiah, Paul affirms that spiritual blindness was foretold and finds fulfillment in their rejection of Christ.

verses.text: 'For this people's heart has grown dull, and with their ears they can barely hear, and their eyes they have closed; otherwise they might see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn, and I would heal them.'
verses.comment: Paul uses Isaiah to emphasize the need for faith and openness to God’s work; salvation is offered, but must be received.

verses.text: Therefore let it be known to you that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen.
verses.comment: The mission to the Gentiles is declared. This reflects the universal scope of the gospel, the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise to Abraham (Gen. 12:3).

verses.text: When he had said these words, the Jews departed, having a great discussion among themselves.
verses.comment: Paul’s bold proclamation divides his hearers, showing the gospel is a matter for the conscience and heart.

verses.text: He lived there two whole years at his own expense and welcomed all who came to him,
verses.comment: Paul’s open ministry in Rome prefigures the Church’s openness to all peoples and the ongoing preaching of the gospel from the heart of the world.

verses.text: proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.
verses.comment: Acts ends with the gospel going out freely from Rome, the world’s capital, anticipating the ongoing and growing mission of the Church to all nations, under apostolic authority, and with the leadership centered in the city of Rome.
